text: Hi everyone, I just started working on paid marketing (PPC) and would really appreciate if you can share some good resources for the same. (Cant afford paid ones)

elements.text: Hi everyone, I just started working on paid marketing (PPC) and would really appreciate if you can share some good resources for the same. (Cant afford paid ones)

text:
Hi everyone, does anyone have template for reaching out to professionals for comments or quotes for articles you're working on?

I'd be happy to learn about outreach tips in general.
Thank you!

text: Hello! I’m trying to gauge a reasonable pricing structure for sponsored blog posts. Our team produces the content (w/ the brand’s input and approval) & it’s published on our blog (~8M sessions/month) for at least a year. Does anyone have experience pricing an offering like this?

elements.text: Hello! I’m trying to gauge a reasonable pricing structure for sponsored blog posts. Our team produces the content (w/ the brand’s input and approval) & it’s published on our blog (~8M sessions/month) for at least a year. Does anyone have experience pricing an offering like this?

text: Hey everyone! Our team is working on content brainstorming for 2022 and I'm curious... what is the best/most impressive marketing campaign you've seen this year and why? Doesn't have to be exclusive to B2B or SaaS, but please include any and all info you have (goal, results, etc.). Feel free to plug yourself but it better be good :wink:

elements.text: Hey everyone! Our team is working on content brainstorming for 2022 and I'm curious... what is the best/most impressive marketing campaign you've seen this year and why? Doesn't have to be exclusive to B2B or SaaS, but please include any and all info you have (goal, results, etc.). Feel free to plug yourself but it better be good

text:
This is always an interesting dilemma. Much of it depends on how content savvy your customer is. Trying to sell to those who still live in the billboard era might be a waste of time no matter how well structured your pricing scheme is, so one of the first things to do is some market research on potential buyers.

You'll be pricing two things: the value of the creation and then the value of the distribution. First part's easier—there will be standard rates for articles out there, based on word count or depth of research, etc. If you keep the IP then I'd expect a big ole discount. How's SEO come into play? Any canonical linking going on?

Second part's tougher. If I were buying from you I'd want some sense of how your big pile of traffic translates into value for me. Yeah yeah 8M/month, but what % of that is going to read this article? What % is relevant to my business? How do you weave my business into the story of the piece? Is it just a byline and product plug somewhere? I assume there will trackable links back to something I own—but it'd be a tricky thing for you guarantee any minimum number of clicks there. You can claim "awareness! The goodwill of being seen!" etc., but I've never really seen that approach (true as it might be) sway many execs.

So you might get into something like:

Base fee + optional retain-IP fee + packages of X, Y, Z months of "hosting."

text: Thank you for this super thoughtful answer - it’s extremely helpful for thinking through how to approach this! :slightly_smiling_face: Would you mind if I PM-ed you a few clarification questions? (want to share some specifics of our program)

elements.text: Thank you for this super thoughtful answer - it’s extremely helpful for thinking through how to approach this!
Would you mind if I PM-ed you a few clarification questions? (want to share some specifics of our program)
